subsection.content: The Chief Electoral Officer must supply to the Presiding Officer a list of the names of the polling officers appointed for the polling station for which that Presiding Officer is appointed.

The Chief Electoral Officer must supply to the Returning Officer for a constituency a list of the polling officers appointed for the polling stations at which polling for that constituency is to take place.

subsection.leadIn: The Presiding Officer must display the list referred to in subsection (1) in a prominent place— (L.N. 74 of 2011)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: (if the polling station for which the Officer is appointed is not a dedicated polling station) outside the polling station; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: (if the polling station for which the Officer is appointed is a dedicated polling station) inside the polling station. (L.N. 74 of 2011)

section.name: s42
section.heading: Presiding Officer to exhibit at polling station notice providing information for the guidance of electors

subsection.leadIn: The Presiding Officer of a polling station must ensure that a notice providing information for the guidance of electors in voting procedure is— (L.N. 131 of 2009)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: exhibited—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: if the polling station is not a dedicated polling station, outside the polling station; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if the polling station is a dedicated polling station, inside the polling station; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: exhibited inside every voting compartment of the polling station.

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: The Presiding Officer of a small polling station or a special polling station must ensure that, before the commencement of the poll, a notice providing information of the main counting station designated for counting the votes cast at the polling station is exhibited outside the polling station. (L.N. 79 of 2007)

subsection.name: 1B
subsection.leadIn: The Presiding Officer of a dedicated polling station must ensure that, before the commencement of the poll, there is exhibited inside the polling station a notice providing—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: information of the ballot paper sorting station, if any, designated for sorting the ballot papers received from the polling station; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: information of the main counting station designated for counting the votes cast at the polling station. (L.N. 131 of 2009)

subsection.content: A notice under subsection (1) must be in the specified form.

section.name: s43
section.heading: Returning Officer to determine no canvassing zones and no staying zones

subsection.content: The Returning Officer for a constituency must determine an area outside each polling station used for polling for that constituency as a no canvassing zone and an area within that area as a no staying zone. A no canvassing zone and a no staying zone are to be determined with reference to a map or plan.
If the polling station is to be used for only one constituency, the Returning Officer for the constituency must give notice to the candidates for that constituency.

subsection.leadIn: If a polling station is to be used for polling for more than one constituency, the determination of the no canvassing zone and the no staying zone is to be made by the Returning Officer specified for the purpose by the Chief Electoral Officer. The Returning Officer who makes the determination must give notice to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the candidates for the constituency for which that Officer is appointed; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Returning Officers for the other constituencies.

subsection.content: Notice under subsection (2) or (3) must be given at least 7 days before polling day.

A Returning Officer who is given notice under subsection (3) must give notice to the candidates for the constituency for which that Officer is appointed, as soon as practicable after that Officer receives the notice.

A Returning Officer who makes a determination of a no canvassing zone or a no staying zone may vary either or both those areas in accordance with this section. Subject to subsection (10), notice of a variation must be given as soon as practicable after the variation in the same manner as notice of a no canvassing zone or a no staying zone is given under subsection (2) or (3).

On polling day, the Returning Officer who has determined the no canvassing zone or the no staying zone (or subsequently varied it, if applicable) must display at or near the polling station a notice of the no canvassing zone and the no staying zone. That Officer must also indicate the boundaries of those zones in a manner that Officer thinks fit.

If after display under subsection (7), either or both of those areas are varied, the Returning Officer must display at or near the polling station a notice of the no canvassing zone or the no staying zone or both those zones, if appropriate, as varied.

subsection.name: 8A
subsection.content: A Returning Officer may perform any act which that Officer is required or authorized to perform under subsections (6), (7) and (8) through a Presiding Officer. (L.N. 79 of 2007)
A determination of a no canvassing zone or a no staying zone or the variation of such an area becomes effective only on the display of a notice under subsection (7) or (8), as may be applicable.

A notice of a variation under subsection (8) need not be given to the candidates if it is not reasonably practicable to do so before the close of the poll. Notice may be given to the election agent or polling agent of a candidate if present at the polling station.
A notice required to be given to a candidate under this section may be given to the election agent or polling agent of the candidate instead of the candidate.

subsection.def: For the purposes of this section notice (通知、公告) means a notice of the determination of the no canvassing zone and the no staying zone with a map or plan or separate maps or plans showing those zones in relation to the relevant polling station.

subsection.leadIn: On polling day, a person must not—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to subsection (14), engage in canvassing votes in a no canvassing zone;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subject to subsection (13A), use a sound amplifying system or device for any purpose in the no canvassing zone; (L.N. 74 of 2011)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: use a sound amplifying system or device, for canvassing votes, so that the sound emitted by it can be heard in the no canvassing zone; (L.N. 125 of 2003)

paragraph.name: ca
paragraph.content: conduct any activity for canvassing votes so that the sound of the activity can be heard in the no canvassing zone; (L.N. 125 of 2003; L.N. 79 of 2007)

paragraph.name: cb
paragraph.leadIn: subject to subsection (15), without reasonable excuse, display or wear in the no canvassing zone any badge, emblem, clothing or head-dress which—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: may promote or prejudice the election of a candidate or candidates at the election; or

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: a body any member of which is standing as a candidate in the election; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: a prescribed body the registered name or registered emblem of which has been printed on any ballot paper for the election; or (L.N. 79 of 2007)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: stay or loiter in the no staying zone without the express permission of the Presiding Officer.

subsection.name: 13A
subsection.content: An officer of the Correctional Services Department may, on polling day, use a sound amplifying system or device for the performance of his or her duties in the no canvassing zone of a dedicated polling station situated in a prison. (L.N. 74 of 2011)

subsection.leadIn: A person may, on polling day, canvass from door to door, without obstructing any person, on the storeys above or below street level, in a building within the no canvassing zone, which—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person is allowed to enter for the purpose of canvassing votes; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has no polling station inside it. (L.N. 125 of 2003)

subsection.content: A person may, for the purpose of canvassing votes as described in subsection (14), display or wear any badge, emblem, clothing or head-dress referred to in subsection (13)(cb). (L.N. 125 of 2003)

section.name: s44
section.heading: Presiding Officer to keep order in no canvassing zone and no staying zone

subsection.leadIn: The Presiding Officer must use that Officer’s best endeavours to ensure that a person does not, on polling day—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: engage in the canvassing of votes in the no canvassing zone (except as provided in section 43(14));

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subject to subsection (1C), use a sound amplifying system or device in the no canvassing zone; (L.N. 74 of 2011)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: use a sound amplifying system or device, for canvassing votes, so that the sound emitted by it can be heard in the no canvassing zone; (L.N. 125 of 2003)

paragraph.name: ca
paragraph.content: conduct any activity for canvassing votes so that the sound of the activity can be heard in the no canvassing zone; (L.N. 125 of 2003; L.N. 79 of 2007)

paragraph.name: cb
paragraph.leadIn: subject to subsection (1B), without reasonable excuse, display or wear in the no canvassing zone any badge, emblem, clothing or head-dress which—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: may promote or prejudice the election of a candidate or candidates at the election; or

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: a body any member of which is standing as a candidate in the election; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: a prescribed body the registered name or registered emblem of which has been printed on any ballot paper for the election; or (L.N. 79 of 2007)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: stay or loiter in the no staying zone (except where the person has been expressly permitted to do so by the Presiding Officer).

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: A person may, on polling day, canvass from door to door, without obstructing any person, on the storeys above or below street level, in a building within the no canvassing zone, which—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person is allowed to enter for the purpose of canvassing votes; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has no polling station inside it. (L.N. 125 of 2003)

subsection.name: 1B
subsection.content: A person may, for the purpose of canvassing votes as described in subsection (1A), display or wear any badge, emblem, clothing or head-dress referred to in subsection (1)(cb). (L.N. 125 of 2003)

subsection.name: 1C
subsection.content: An officer of the Correctional Services Department may, on polling day, use a sound amplifying system or device for the performance of his or her duties in the no canvassing zone of a dedicated polling station situated in a prison. (L.N. 74 of 2011)

subsection.leadIn: If, on polling day, in a no canvassing zone or a no staying zone, a person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: misconducts himself or herself, the Returning Officer or the Presiding Officer may;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: fails to obey a lawful order of the Returning Officer, that Officer may; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: fails to obey a lawful order of the Presiding Officer, that Officer may,

subsection.continued: order the person to leave the no canvassing zone or the no staying zone, as the case may be, immediately.

subsection.leadIn: If a person fails to leave when ordered to do so under subsection (2), the person may be removed by— (L.N. 131 of 2009)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a police officer;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person authorized in writing by the Returning Officer or the Presiding Officer, as may be appropriate; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if the no canvassing zone or the no staying zone, as may be appropriate, is determined in relation to a dedicated polling station, an officer of the Correctional Services Department or any law enforcement agency. (L.N. 131 of 2009)

subsection.content: A person who is removed under subsection (3) may not enter the relevant zone again on that day, unless the Returning Officer or the Presiding Officer, as the case may be, permits him or her to do so. (L.N. 79 of 2007)
The powers conferred by this section are not to be exercised so as to prevent a person from voting at the polling station allocated to that person.

section.name: s45
section.heading: Candidates may appoint polling agents

subsection.content: A candidate may appoint persons to attend at polling stations on his or her behalf for any purpose connected with the conduct of a poll, in accordance with this section.
Polling agents may be appointed to attend only at the polling stations used for polling for the constituency for which the candidate is standing for election.
A candidate may appoint a maximum of 2 polling agents for one polling station.
Only a person who is a holder of an identity card and has attained the age of 18 years may be appointed as a polling agent.
A candidate must give notice of appointment of a polling agent to the Returning Officer at least 7 days before polling day. (L.N. 125 of 2003)

subsection.name: 5A
subsection.leadIn: Despite subsections (1), (3) and (5)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to paragraphs (b) and (c), only one polling agent may be appointed by a candidate for a dedicated polling station situated in a prison;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: no polling agent may be appointed by a candidate for a dedicated polling station situated in a prison if the Commissioner of Correctional Services has consented under section 26(15)(d) to the presence of the election agent of that candidate in that polling station;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: no polling agent may be appointed for a dedicated polling station situated in a maximum security prison; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: the appointment of a polling agent for a dedicated polling station situated in a prison is not effective unless— (12 of 2014 s. 44)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a notice of appointment is given to the Chief Electoral Officer at least 7 days before polling day; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the Commissioner of Correctional Services consents to the appointment. (L.N. 131 of 2009; 12 of 2014 s. 44)

subsection.name: 5B
subsection.leadIn: Despite subsection (5A)(d), even though a notice of appointment is given during the week before polling day, the Commissioner of Correctional Services may still give consent under that subsection if the Commissioner is satisfied that— (12 of 2014 s. 44)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an elector in custody who is entitled to vote for the relevant constituency at the polling station concerned is admitted or transferred to the prison concerned during that week; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the notice of appointment is given without undue delay after the admission or transfer. (L.N. 131 of 2009; 12 of 2014 s. 44)

subsection.name: 5C
subsection.content: If the Commissioner of Correctional Services refuses to give consent under subsection (5A)(d), the Commissioner must notify the candidate or the election agent of the candidate as soon as practicable. (L.N. 131 of 2009)

subsection.name: 5D
subsection.content: A notice of appointment given under subsection (5) or (5A)(d) must be delivered by hand, by post, by electronic mail or by facsimile transmission. (12 of 2014 s. 44)

subsection.leadIn: A notice appointing a polling agent for a polling station other than a dedicated polling station situated in a prison must, if it is not given under subsection (5), be delivered on the polling day to the Presiding Officer of the polling station— (L.N. 131 of 2009)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by the candidate in person; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by the election agent of the candidate, in person.

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (5A)(d), the appointment of a polling agent is not effective until notice of the appointment is received by the Returning Officer or the Presiding Officer, as may be appropriate. (12 of 2014 s. 44)

A notice of appointment must be in writing and in the specified form. It must state the name, identity card number and residential address of the polling agent. It must be signed by the candidate. (12 of 2014 s. 44)

If the appointment of a polling agent is revoked, the candidate must give notice of the revocation to the Returning Officer or the Presiding Officer of the polling station in accordance with subsection (11) or (11A). (12 of 2014 s. 44)
A notice of revocation must be in writing and in the specified form. It must be signed by the candidate. (12 of 2014 s. 44)

If the notice of revocation is given before polling day, it must be delivered to the Returning Officer by hand, by post, by electronic mail or by facsimile transmission. (L.N. 74 of 2011; 12 of 2014 s. 44)

subsection.name: 11A
subsection.leadIn: If the notice of revocation is given on the polling day—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: (if the polling station for which the polling agent is appointed is not a dedicated polling station situated in a prison) it must be delivered to the Presiding Officer of the polling station—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: by the candidate in person; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: by the election agent of the candidate, in person; or (12 of 2014 s. 44)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: (if the polling station for which the polling agent is appointed is a dedicated polling station situated in a prison) it must be delivered to the Returning Officer by hand, by electronic mail or by facsimile transmission. (12 of 2014 s. 44)

subsection.content: The revocation of the appointment of a polling agent is not effective until notice of revocation is received by the Returning Officer or the Presiding Officer, as the case may be.

section.name: s46
section.heading: Chief Electoral Officer to delineate polling stations on a map and display map

subsection.content: The Chief Electoral Officer must delineate each polling station on one or more maps or plans. (L.N. 131 of 2009)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: The Chief Electoral Officer must display a map or plan referred to in subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to paragraph (b), outside the polling station concerned; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the map or plan is prepared for a dedicated polling station, inside the polling station. (L.N. 131 of 2009)

subsection.content: The Presiding Officer must demarcate clearly by marks, barriers or other means as that Officer thinks fit, the polling station in accordance with the map or plan referred to in subsection (1).
The Chief Electoral Officer and the Presiding Officer must carry out their functions under this section before the poll commences.

section.name: s47
section.heading: Who may enter or be present at a polling station

subsection.content: Except where it is provided otherwise in this Regulation, a person must not enter a polling station other than to vote.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsections (4) and (5), in order to ensure that polling takes place smoothly and efficiently, the Presiding Officer may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: regulate the number of electors, candidates, election agents and polling agents to be admitted to the polling station at any one time; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: exclude any person from the polling station.

subsection.content: Without limiting subsection (2), the Presiding Officer may exclude from the polling station any person who is present in contravention of this section.

subsection.leadIn: The Presiding Officer may not exclude from the polling station—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a polling officer;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Returning Officer or Assistant Returning Officers for the constituency or constituencies for which the polling station is used;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: members of the Commission;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the Chief Electoral Officer;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: police officers and members of the Civil Aid Service on duty at the polling station; (L.N. 125 of 2003)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: public officers authorized in writing by the Chief Electoral Officer; (L.N. 125 of 2003)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: persons authorized in writing by a member of the Commission; (L.N. 125 of 2003; L.N. 79 of 2007)

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: a person authorized in writing by the Returning Officer to act as a liaison officer; (L.N. 125 of 2003; L.N. 79 of 2007; 14 of 2021 s. 163)

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: public officers on duty at the polling station; or (L.N. 79 of 2007; 14 of 2021 s. 163)

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: an individual who provides the assistance mentioned in section 112(2)(c) pursuant to an authorization under that section. (14 of 2021 s. 163)

subsection.content: A person authorized by the Commission to be present in a polling station may be present in accordance with the terms of the authorization.
Subject to subsections (7), (8), (9), (10), (11) and (12), on behalf of each candidate, one polling agent of that candidate may be present in the polling station at any one time.

subsection.name: 6A
subsection.content: Subsection (6) does not apply to a dedicated polling station situated in a maximum security prison. (L.N. 131 of 2009)
If a candidate is present in the polling station, the election agent or polling agent of that candidate may not be present in that polling station at the same time.
If the election agent of a candidate is present in the polling station, a polling agent of that candidate may not be present in that polling station at the same time.
A candidate, an election agent or polling agent may be present in the polling station subject to the availability of seats in the area designated to accommodate them.

A person referred to in subsection (9) who wishes to be admitted to the polling station must, on arriving at the polling station, report in person to the Presiding Officer and produce his or her identity card and a declaration of secrecy completed on the specified form by him or her.

If the area referred to in subsection (9) is occupied to its full seating capacity, the Presiding Officer may refuse entry to the polling station to any person referred to in that subsection. That Officer may make arrangements for admitting them to the polling station later.
Only an election agent or polling agent regarding whom notice of appointment has been given under this Regulation may be present at a polling station on behalf of a candidate.

subsection.leadIn: If a person who is accompanied by a child arrives at a polling station for the purpose of voting, the Presiding Officer may permit the child to enter the polling station if that Officer considers that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the child should not be left unattended while the person is in the polling station; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the child will not disturb or cause inconvenience to any person in the polling station. (L.N. 79 of 2007)

subsection.content: The Presiding Officer must not exercise the powers conferred on that Officer under this section so as to prevent a person from voting at the polling station allocated to that person.

section.name: s48
section.heading: What constitutes an offence at a polling station

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (6), if on polling day, within a polling station, a person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: communicates with an elector; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: uses a mobile telephone, paging machine or any other device for electronic communication,

subsection.continued: contrary to a direction of the Returning Officer, Assistant Returning Officer, Presiding Officer or any polling officer not to do so, that person commits an offence. (L.N. 125 of 2003; L.N. 79 of 2007; L.N. 74 of 2011)

subsection.leadIn: A person who, on polling day, films or takes photographs or makes any audio or video recording within a polling station without the express permission of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Presiding Officer;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Returning Officer for the constituency or constituencies for which the polling station is used; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any member of the Commission,

subsection.continued: commits an offence.

subsection.content: A person who, on polling day, engages in the canvassing of votes or displays an election advertisement within a polling station commits an offence.

A person who, on polling day, fails to comply with a lawful order given by the Returning Officer or the Presiding Officer or behaves in a disorderly manner in a no canvassing zone or a no staying zone or within or at a polling station or contravenes section 43(13) or 44(4), commits an offence.

subsection.leadIn: A person who, on polling day, displays or wears in the no canvassing zone, without reasonable excuse (except as provided in section 43(15)), any badge, emblem, clothing or head-dress which—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may promote or prejudice the election of a candidate or candidates at the election; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: makes direct reference to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a body any member of which is standing as a candidate in the election; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a prescribed body the registered name or registered emblem of which has been printed on any ballot paper for the election, (L.N. 79 of 2007)

subsection.continued: commits an offence. (L.N. 125 of 2003)

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) does not apply to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a Returning Officer and an Assistant Returning Officer for the constituency or constituencies for which the polling station is used; (L.N. 125 of 2003)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a member of the Commission;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the Chief Electoral Officer;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a person authorized in writing by a member of the Commission to so communicate;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: a Presiding Officer;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: a polling officer;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: a person authorized in writing by the Returning Officer to act as a liaison officer;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: a police officer on duty at a polling station; (L.N. 131 of 2009 and L.N. 197 of 2009)

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: a member of the Civil Aid Service on duty at a polling station; (L.N. 131 of 2009 and L.N. 197 of 2009)

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: an officer of the Correctional Services Department on duty at a dedicated polling station; or (L.N. 131 of 2009 and L.N. 197 of 2009)

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: an officer of any law enforcement agency on duty at a dedicated polling station. (L.N. 131 of 2009 and L.N. 197 of 2009)

subsection.content: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1), (3), (4) or (5) is liable to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 3 months. (L.N. 79 of 2007)
A person who commits an offence under subsection (2) is liable to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (L.N. 79 of 2007)

section.name: s49
section.heading: Presiding Officer to keep order at the polling station

subsection.content: The Presiding Officer must keep order at the polling station.

subsection.leadIn: If, on polling day, in the polling station or its vicinity, a person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: misconducts himself or herself, the Returning Officer or the Presiding Officer may;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: fails to obey a lawful order of the Returning Officer, that Officer may; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: fails to obey a lawful order of the Presiding Officer, that Officer may,

subsection.continued: order the person to leave the polling station or the vicinity of the polling station, as the case may be, immediately.

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.content: If an elector who is allocated to vote at a dedicated polling station fails to cast his or her vote without undue delay pursuant to section 57(3), the Returning Officer or the Presiding Officer may order him or her to leave the polling station immediately. (L.N. 131 of 2009)

subsection.leadIn: If a person fails to leave when ordered to do so under subsection (2) or (2A), the person may be removed— (L.N. 131 of 2009)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the polling station is not a dedicated polling station, by a police officer or by a person authorized in writing by the Returning Officer or the Presiding Officer, as may be appropriate; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if the polling station is a dedicated polling station, by—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a person authorized in writing by the Returning Officer or the Presiding Officer, as may be appropriate;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: an officer of the Correctional Services Department; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: an officer of any law enforcement agency. (L.N. 131 of 2009)

subsection.content: A person who is removed under subsection (3) may not enter the relevant polling station again on that day, unless the Returning Officer or the Presiding Officer, as the case may be, permits him or her to do so.
The powers conferred by subsection (2) are not to be exercised so as to prevent a person from voting at the polling station allocated to that person. (L.N. 131 of 2009)

division.name: D2
division.heading: Ballot Boxes and Ballot Papers and Procedure for Voting

section.name: s50
section.heading: Design of ballot box
section.content: A ballot box to be used for an election is to be so constructed that ballot papers can be introduced into it while it is locked but cannot be withdrawn from it without unlocking it or breaking the seal or the sealing device.

section.name: s51
section.heading: Presiding Officer to seal ballot box before commencement of poll

subsection.content: Immediately before the commencement of the poll, the Presiding Officer must show each ballot box, empty, to the persons, if any, as are then present within the polling station. Then the Presiding Officer must lock the ballot box, seal it with a seal provided for that purpose or any other device specified by the Chief Electoral Officer, so that it cannot be opened without breaking the seal or the device.
The Presiding Officer must place the ballot box for the receipt of ballot papers in that Officer’s view or in the view of any other polling officer, and must keep it locked and sealed.

section.name: s52
section.heading: Form of ballot paper and order of appearance of names of candidates on ballot papers

subsection.content: A ballot paper to be used to vote for a District Committees constituency is to be in Form 1 in Schedule 2. (19 of 2023 s. 138)

subsection.name: 1AA
subsection.content: A ballot paper to be used to vote for a District Council geographical constituency is to be in Form 2 in Schedule 2. (19 of 2023 s. 138)

subsection.name: 1AAB
subsection.content: If the Commission has made a direction under section 57A(2) in relation to a by-election for a District Committees constituency, a ballot paper to be used to vote at that by-election is to be in Form 3 in Schedule 2. (19 of 2023 s. 138)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: The Chief Electoral Officer may modify the layout of the form of a ballot paper prescribed in Schedule 2 (except Forms 1 and 3 in that Schedule) to incorporate particulars relating to candidates to be printed on a ballot paper in accordance with the Particulars Relating to Candidates on Ballot Papers (Legislative Council and District Councils) Regulation (Cap. 541 sub. leg. M). (L.N. 79 of 2007; 19 of 2023 s. 138)

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may decide—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to have a ballot paper printed in white or in colour or colour pattern;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the colour in which a ballot paper is to be printed or the colour pattern to be printed on a ballot paper;

paragraph.name: ba
paragraph.content: to have different types of ballot paper printed in different colours or with different colour patterns; (19 of 2023 s. 138)

paragraph.name: c
d
paragraph.content: the design to be printed on the back of a ballot paper; or (19 of 2023 s. 138)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: to have different designs printed on the back of different types of ballot papers. (19 of 2023 s. 138)

subsection.content: The Commission may assign a code for each constituency. The code is to be printed on the front of a ballot paper.

The order in which the names of candidates appear on a ballot paper is to be determined by the Returning Officer by the drawing of lots. A number is to be allocated to each candidate according to the result of the draw.
A candidate may be present at the drawing of lots under this section or be represented by a person authorized in writing by him or her.
The Returning Officer must give notice to each candidate of the arrangements for the drawing of lots under this section.

subsection.leadIn: A ballot paper is to contain the following information—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the name of the candidate;

paragraph.name: aa
paragraph.content: insofar as may be applicable to the candidate, the particulars specified in the Schedule to the Particulars Relating to Candidates on Ballot Papers (Legislative Council and District Councils) Regulation (Cap. 541 sub. leg. M); and (L.N. 79 of 2007; L.N. 144 of 2019)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the number allocated to the candidate under this section.

subsection.leadIn: In the case of death or disqualification of a candidate who has been allocated a number under this section, the name of the candidate and the information under subsection (7) relating to that candidate—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: are to be omitted from the ballot paper; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if printed on the ballot paper, are to be crossed out under section 40(2). (1 of 2019 s. 37)

subsection.content: The number allocated to a candidate under this section is not to be altered even if the information relating to another candidate for the constituency concerned who has died or is disqualified is omitted from the ballot paper or crossed out under subsection (8).
A ballot paper is to have the date and description of the election printed on the front of it.
A number may be printed on the counterfoil of a ballot paper, but that number is not to be printed or shown in any manner on the ballot paper.
A notice required to be given to a candidate under subsection (6) may be given to the election agent instead of the candidate.

section.name: s52A
section.heading: Arrangement for giving ballot papers to elderly persons, pregnant women, etc.

subsection.leadIn: The Presiding Officer may designate an area in the polling station for giving a ballot paper to a person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: who is not less than 70 years of age;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: whose document specified in section 53(1A)(a), (ab), (b), (c), (d), (e) or (f) shows the year of birth, without the month and day of birth, of the person which is 70 years earlier than the year within which the polling day falls;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: whose document specified in section 53(1A)(a), (ab), (b), (c), (d), (e) or (f) shows, without the day of birth—

subparagraph.content: the year of birth of the person which is 70 years earlier than the year within which the polling day falls; and
the month of birth of the person which is the same as the month within which the polling day falls;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: who is pregnant; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: who, because of illness, injury, disability or dependence on mobility aids—

subparagraph.content: is not able to queue for a long time; or
has difficulty in queuing.

subsection.leadIn: If the Presiding Officer is satisfied that a person who arrives at, or is present in, the polling station to vote falls within the description in subsection (1)(a), (b), (c), (d) or (e), the Officer may direct the person to immediately proceed to the following location to apply for a ballot paper—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the area designated under subsection (1); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if there is a queue extending from that area—the end of the queue.

section.name: s53
section.heading: Ballot paper to be given to a person only if Presiding Officer is satisfied of the person’s identity

subsection.content: The Presiding Officer must not give a ballot paper to a person unless that Officer is satisfied, by inspecting the document or documents set out in subsection (1A) or (1B), that he or she is the person registered in the final register, whom he or she claims to be. (L.N. 130 of 2017)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: For a person applying for a ballot paper at a polling station (other than a dedicated polling station situated in a prison), the document or documents referred to in subsection (1) are any of the following—

paragraph.name: a
ab
paragraph.content: a document issued by the Commissioner (within the meaning of section 1A(1) of the Registration of Persons Ordinance (Cap. 177)) (Commissioner of Registration) to the person certifying that the person is exempt, under regulation 25 of the Registration of Persons Regulations (Cap. 177 sub. leg. A), from being required to register under that Ordinance; (L.N. 149 of 2018)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a document issued by the Commissioner of Registration acknowledging that the person has applied—

subparagraph.content: to be registered under the Registration of Persons Ordinance (Cap. 177); or

paragraph.name: c
d
e
f
paragraph.leadIn: both— (L.N. 149 of 2018)

subparagraph.content: a document evidencing a report to a police officer of the loss or destruction of the document referred to in paragraph (a), (ab) or (b); and (L.N. 149 of 2018)
a valid passport or similar travel document (not being one referred to in another paragraph in this subsection) issued to the person showing the person’s name and photograph. (L.N. 149 of 2018)

subsection.name: 1B
subsection.leadIn: For a person applying for a ballot paper at a dedicated polling station situated in a prison, the document referred to in subsection (1) is a document issued by the Commissioner of Correctional Services showing—

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: the person’s name;

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: the person’s photograph; and

subparagraph.name: c
subparagraph.content: the prisoner registration number allocated by that Commissioner to the person for identification purposes. (L.N. 130 of 2017)

subsection.leadIn: A person is not to be prevented from voting only due to an omission or inaccuracy of a particular required to be recorded in a final register, other than—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of the first ordinary election, the omission of both the person’s name and identity document number from the copy of the part of the final register supplied to the Presiding Officer; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of any subsequent ordinary election, the omission of both the person’s name and identity document number from the final register.

section.name: s54
section.heading: Questions to be asked from persons applying for a ballot paper

subsection.content: The Presiding Officer may, at the time a person applies for a ballot paper, but not afterwards, ask, in case of doubt, the appropriate questions set out in subsection (2).

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: When asking the questions, the Presiding Officer must have regard to whether the ballot paper applied for is a DCC ballot paper or a GC ballot paper, and that Officer must choose, frame, adjust or modify the questions accordingly. (19 of 2023 s. 139)

subsection.leadIn: The questions referred to in subsection (1) are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: “Are you the person registered in the final register now in effect for this District Committees constituency, as follows (the Presiding Officer to read the whole entry as it is recorded in the copy or extract of the final register supplied to that Officer)?” or “你是否已登記在對本地區委員會界別有效的正式選民冊上的人，並且有關記項一如以下所述 (the Presiding Officer to read the whole entry as it is recorded in the copy or extract of the final register supplied to that Officer)?”;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: “Are you the person registered in the final register now in effect for this District Council geographical constituency, as follows (the Presiding Officer to read the whole entry as it is recorded in the copy or extract of the final register supplied to that Officer)?” or “你是否已登記在對本區議會地方選區有效的正式選民冊上的人，並且有關記項一如以下所述 (the Presiding Officer to read the whole entry as it is recorded in the copy or extract of the final register supplied to that Officer)?”;

paragraph.name: c
d
paragraph.content: “Have you already voted for this or any other District Council geographical constituency in this election?” or “在這次選舉中，你是否已經就本區議會地方選區或任何其他區議會地方選區投票?”. (19 of 2023 s. 139)

subsection.content: The Presiding Officer must ask the appropriate questions set out in subsection (2) if so required by a candidate, an election agent or a polling agent.
The Presiding Officer must not give a ballot paper to any person who fails to answer the questions asked of that person under this section to the satisfaction of that Officer.

section.name: s55
section.heading: A candidate or election agent or polling agent may challenge a person who has applied for a ballot paper or who has voted

subsection.content: If a candidate, an election agent or a polling agent declares to the Presiding Officer that he or she has reasonable cause to believe that a person has engaged in corrupt conduct by impersonation and undertakes in writing to substantiate the allegation in a court, the Presiding Officer may take the step specified in subsection (2A). A candidate or an election agent or a polling agent may so declare only at the time a person applies for the ballot paper or after a person has applied for a ballot paper and before he or she has left the polling station.

If the Presiding Officer has reason to believe that a person applying for a ballot paper or who has applied for a ballot paper and who has not left the polling station has engaged in corrupt conduct by impersonation, the Presiding Officer may take the step specified in subsection (2A).

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.leadIn: The step specified for the purposes of subsections (1) and (2) is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the polling station is not a dedicated polling station, requesting a police officer to arrest the person concerned; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the polling station is a dedicated polling station, requesting an officer of the Correctional Services Department or any law enforcement agency to remove the person concerned from the polling station and report the case to the police. (L.N. 131 of 2009)

subsection.content: A person regarding whom a declaration is made under subsection (1) (whether or not that person is arrested or removed under that subsection) or a person who has been arrested or removed pursuant to a request made under subsection (2) is not to be prevented from voting only by reason of the declaration, arrest or removal. (L.N. 74 of 2011)

In this section, the reference to corrupt conduct by impersonation is to be construed as the corrupt conduct referred to in section 15 of the Elections (Corrupt and Illegal Conduct) Ordinance (Cap. 554). (10 of 2000 s. 47)

section.name: s56
section.heading: Presiding Officer to issue only one ballot paper to an elector for a constituency

subsection.content: The Presiding Officer is to issue only one ballot paper to an elector who applies for a ballot paper for a constituency. (19 of 2023 s. 140)
Before issuing a ballot paper under this section, the name of the elector as stated in the copy or extract of the relevant final register supplied under section 40(3) must be called out.

subsection.leadIn: Immediately before issuing the ballot paper, the Presiding Officer must— (14 of 2021 s. 165)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if a printed copy or extract of the relevant final register is used to record the issue—mark the copy or extract by placing a line across the name and identity document number of the elector; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if an FR electronic copy or extract (as defined by section 110) of the relevant final register is used to record the issue—make, by using an electronic device, a record in the entry relating to the elector in the FR electronic copy or extract,

subsection.continued: to denote that the ballot paper the elector is entitled to have issued to him or her at the relevant polling station has been so issued. (14 of 2021 s. 165)

subsection.content: No record is to be made of the particular ballot paper issued to an elector.

section.name: s56A
section.heading: Elector who has not cast vote may return to cast vote with permission

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (5), if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an elector has been issued with a ballot paper for a constituency; and (19 of 2023 s. 141)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he or she has left the polling station without casting his or her vote,

subsection.continued: he or she shall not cast the vote when he or she returns to the polling station before the close of the poll unless—

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: before leaving the polling station, he or she has—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: made a request to the Presiding Officer for permission to cast the vote before the close of the poll;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: informed the Presiding Officer of his or her reason for leaving the polling station without casting the vote; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: returned the ballot paper, unmarked, to the Presiding Officer; (L.N. 131 of 2009)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the Presiding Officer has granted the requested permission; and (L.N. 131 of 2009)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: if the polling station is a dedicated polling station situated in a prison, the elector returns to the polling station within the time slot assigned to him or her under subsection (2A) or section 30(2A). (L.N. 131 of 2009)

subsection.content: If an elector has complied with subsection (1)(c), the Presiding Officer must grant the permission unless he or she is of the opinion that the request is a manifest abuse of the facilities provided by this section.

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.leadIn: If the Presiding Officer of a dedicated polling station situated in a prison grants the permission to an elector under subsection (1), the Commissioner of Correctional Services must, as far as practicable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: assign to the elector a new time slot during the polling hours appointed for the polling station; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: notify the elector of the new time slot. (L.N. 131 of 2009)

subsection.leadIn: If the Presiding Officer grants the permission to an elector under subsection (2), he or she must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: keep in his or her custody the ballot paper returned by the elector under subsection (1)(c)(iii); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on the elector’s return to the polling station before the close of the poll to cast the vote, re-issue the ballot paper to the elector in the presence of a police officer or, if the polling station is a dedicated polling station, an officer of the Correctional Services Department or any law enforcement agency. (L.N. 131 of 2009)

subsection.content: If the Presiding Officer does not grant the permission to an elector under subsection (2), he or she must immediately re-issue to the elector the ballot paper returned under subsection (1)(c)(iii).

subsection.leadIn: An elector who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has been issued with a ballot paper for a constituency; (19 of 2023 s. 141)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has become incapacitated from voting by physical illness; and (L.N. 191 of 2003)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: has left the polling station after—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: returning the ballot paper, unmarked, to the Presiding Officer; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: leaving the ballot paper, unmarked, behind in the polling station without putting the ballot paper into the ballot box (if the Presiding Officer is aware that the elector has so left the ballot paper behind before leaving the polling station),

subsection.continued: may return to the polling station before the close of the poll and cast his or her vote.

subsection.name: 5A
subsection.leadIn: If an elector in custody leaves a dedicated polling station situated in a prison under subsection (5), the Commissioner of Correctional Services must, as far as practicable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: assign to the elector a new time slot during the polling hours appointed for the polling station; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: notify the elector of the new time slot. (L.N. 131 of 2009)

subsection.name: 5B
subsection.content: The right of an elector in custody who is allocated to vote at a dedicated polling station situated in a prison to cast the vote under subsection (5) is subject to the elector’s returning to the polling station within the time slot assigned to him or her under subsection (5A) or section 30(2A). (L.N. 131 of 2009)

subsection.leadIn: If any ballot paper is returned under subsection (5)(c)(i) or left behind in the polling station under subsection (5)(c)(ii) by an elector, the Presiding Officer must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: keep in his or her custody the ballot paper; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on the elector’s return to the polling station before the close of the poll to cast the vote, re-issue the ballot paper to the elector in the presence of a police officer or, if the polling station is a dedicated polling station, an officer of the Correctional Services Department or any law enforcement agency. (L.N. 131 of 2009)

subsection.content: For the purposes of this Regulation, re-issuing a ballot paper under subsection (3), (4) or (6) shall be regarded as issuing a ballot paper under section 56(1).

section.name: s57
section.heading: Procedure for voting

subsection.content: When an elector is issued with a ballot paper for a constituency, he or she must immediately go into a voting compartment and mark the ballot paper. (L.N. 131 of 2009; 19 of 2023 s. 142)

After marking the ballot paper, the elector must, before leaving the voting compartment, conceal the mark on it as directed by the Commission under subsection (2A). (L.N. 131 of 2009; 19 of 2023 s. 142)

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.leadIn: The Commission may direct, in a way it considers appropriate, the elector—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to put the ballot paper, unfolded, into the ballot box with the marked side facing down;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: to—

subparagraph.content: fold the ballot paper so that the marked side is inside; and
put the folded ballot paper into the ballot box;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: to—

subparagraph.content: put the ballot paper, unfolded, into an envelope provided at the polling station; and
put the ballot paper contained in the envelope into the ballot box; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: to—

subparagraph.content: fold the ballot paper so that the marked side is inside;
put the folded ballot paper into an envelope provided at the polling station; and
put the ballot paper contained in the envelope into the ballot box. (19 of 2023 s. 142)

subsection.content: An elector must cast his or her vote without undue delay. An elector must leave the polling station as soon as he or she has put the ballot paper into the ballot box.
A person must not put anything other than a marked ballot paper or an envelope referred to in subsection (2A) into the ballot box. (L.N. 131 of 2009)
Except where it is provided otherwise in this Regulation, a person must not remove a ballot paper from a polling station.

subsection.def: In this section voting compartment (投票間) means a compartment provided under section 40(1) for the purpose of marking ballot papers.

section.name: s57A
section.heading: How DCC ballot papers are to be marked

subsection.content: An elector voting for a District Committees constituency must mark the ballot paper by filling in black the ovals on it opposite the names of the candidates of the elector’s choice.

However, the Commission may, in relation to a by-election for a District Committees constituency, direct that the ballot paper must be marked with a chop provided for that purpose by the Chief Electoral Officer at the polling station and bearing the mark “✓”, with or without any design.

subsection.leadIn: If the Commission makes a direction under subsection (2) in relation to a by-election—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an elector voting at the by-election must mark the ballot paper with the chop provided under section 40(7) for the purpose; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the chop is to be affixed to give a single “✓” in each of the circles opposite the names of the candidates of the elector’s choice on the ballot paper.

subsection.content: An elector voting for a District Committees constituency must vote for a number of candidates that is equal to the number of members to be returned for the constituency at the election.

section.name: s58
section.heading: How GC ballot papers are to be marked

subsection.content: An elector voting for a District Council geographical constituency is to mark his or her ballot paper with the chop. (19 of 2023 s. 144)
The chop is to be affixed to give a single “✓” in the circle opposite the name of the candidate of the elector’s choice on the ballot paper.

subsection.def: In this section chop (印章) means a chop provided under section 40(7) for the purpose of marking the ballot paper.

section.name: s59
section.heading: Marking of ballot papers for or by incapacitated person

subsection.content: The Presiding Officer may mark a ballot paper for an elector who is or claims that he or she is unable to read or is incapacitated from voting due to blindness or other physical cause. The Presiding Officer may do so only on the application of such an elector.

The Presiding Officer must mark the ballot paper for a person referred to in subsection (1) in the presence of a polling officer and in the appropriate manner specified in section 57A or 58 (as applicable) according to the choice of the elector. The Presiding Officer must put the ballot paper into the ballot box, in the manner described in section 57 in the presence of a polling officer, after marking it. (19 of 2023 s. 145)
An elector who is blind or claims that he or she is blind may make use of a template to mark the ballot paper if a template is provided for that purpose at the polling station.

section.name: s60
section.heading: When person is to be issued with ballot paper marked “重複” and “TENDERED”

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2) and section 56A, if a person (the first-mentioned person) representing himself or herself to be a particular elector applies for a ballot paper after a person has been issued with a ballot paper on the basis that he or she is that first-mentioned person, the Presiding Officer must issue to the first-mentioned person a ballot paper endorsed on the front of it with the words “重複” and “TENDERED”.

subsection.leadIn: The Presiding Officer may issue a ballot paper under subsection (1) only if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Presiding Officer is not certain that the first-mentioned person is the person who has been issued with a ballot paper; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the first-mentioned person answers the appropriate questions set out in section 54 to the satisfaction of the Presiding Officer.

section.name: s61
section.heading: What ballot papers are to be marked “未用” and “UNUSED” by the Presiding Officer

subsection.content: Unless it is not reasonably practicable to do so, the Presiding Officer must endorse the words “未用” and “UNUSED” on any ballot paper that has been issued but has not been put into the ballot box.

References in this Regulation to an unused ballot paper are to be construed as references to a ballot paper which has been issued and has not been put into the ballot box, whether or not it has been endorsed under subsection (1).

section.name: s62
section.heading: What ballot papers are to be marked “損壞” and “SPOILT” by the Presiding Officer

subsection.content: If an elector inadvertently deals with the ballot paper issued to him or her in such a manner that it cannot be properly used as a ballot paper or makes an error in marking a ballot paper, he or she may apply to the Presiding Officer for another ballot paper.

The Presiding Officer may issue another ballot paper to a person referred to in subsection (1) if that person gives back the ballot paper already issued to him or her to the Presiding Officer and establishes to the satisfaction of the Presiding Officer the inadvertence or the fact that he or she made an error.
The Presiding Officer must immediately cancel the ballot paper given back to that Officer under subsection (2) by endorsing on the front of it with the words “損壞” and “SPOILT”.

section.name: s63
section.heading: Steps to be taken at the close of the poll: a polling station which is also a counting station

subsection.content: As soon as practicable after the close of the poll at a polling station which is also designated as a counting station, the Presiding Officer must display a notice in a prominent place outside the polling station stating that the poll has been closed and that it will be opened when it is ready for use for the counting of votes. (L.N. 125 of 2003 and L.N. 191 of 2003; L.N. 131 of 2009)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: A candidate, and an election agent, a counting agent and a polling agent of such candidate may stay in a polling station referred to in subsection (1) while it is closed for the preparation for the counting of votes. (L.N. 125 of 2003; L.N. 79 of 2007)

subsection.leadIn: After complying with subsection (1), the Presiding Officer must, in the presence of the persons, if any, who are present within the polling station, take the following steps—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: place the ballot box or boxes where that Officer and other persons who are present within the polling station can see them;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: use a padlock to keep the device secured in position;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: seal each ballot box; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: make up into separate sealed packets—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: ballot papers which have not been issued;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the unused ballot papers;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the spoilt ballot papers; and

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: if the copy or extract of the relevant final register has been marked under section 56(3)(a)—the marked copy or extract. (14 of 2021 s. 166)

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.content: The Presiding Officer must, after complying with subsection (2), keep the sealed ballot box or boxes under that Officer’s control until the counting of votes begins. (L.N. 125 of 2003)
At a polling station used for polling for more than one constituency, the Presiding Officer must make separate sealed packets for each constituency.

For the avoidance of doubt it is stated that the ballot papers in a sealed packet prepared under this section are not to be counted for the purpose of counting of the votes. Accordingly, references to ballot papers in relation to the counting of the votes are to be construed as not including those ballot papers.

section.name: s63A
section.heading: Steps to be taken at the close of the poll: a polling station which is not a counting station

subsection.leadIn: As soon as practicable after the close of the poll at a small polling station, a special polling station or a dedicated polling station, the Presiding Officer of that polling station must, in the presence of the persons, if any, who are present within the polling station, take the following steps— (L.N. 131 of 2009)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: place the ballot box or boxes where that Officer and other persons who are present within the polling station can see them;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: use a padlock to keep the device secured in position;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: seal each ballot box; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: make up into separate sealed packets—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: ballot papers which have not been issued;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the unused ballot papers;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the spoilt ballot papers; and

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: if the copy or extract of the relevant final register has been marked under section 56(3)(a)—the marked copy or extract. (14 of 2021 s. 167)

subsection.content: A candidate and an election agent and a polling agent of such candidate may stay in a polling station referred to in subsection (1) while it is closed for taking the steps referred to in subsection (1)(a), (b), (c), (d) and (e).

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.content: An election agent or a polling agent may not stay under subsection (2) in a dedicated polling station situated in a maximum security prison. (L.N. 131 of 2009)

The Presiding Officer of the small polling station or special polling station must then deliver the ballot box or boxes, the sealed packets and the ballot paper accounts prepared by that Officer to the Presiding Officer of the main counting station. (L.N. 79 of 2007)

The Presiding Officer of the dedicated polling station must then deliver the ballot box or boxes, the sealed packets and the ballot paper accounts prepared by that Officer to the Presiding Officer of the ballot paper sorting station or the main counting station concerned, as advised by the Chief Electoral Officer. (L.N. 131 of 2009; L.N. 197 of 2009)

section.name: s64
section.heading: Presiding Officer to prepare a ballot paper account for each packet of sealed ballot papers

subsection.content: The Presiding Officer (other than the Presiding Officer of a dedicated polling station) must prepare a statement which complies with subsection (2) for each packet prepared under section 63 or 63A, as the case may be, for a constituency. (L.N. 125 of 2003 and L.N. 191 of 2003; L.N. 74 of 2011)

subsection.leadIn: The statement under subsection (1) must be in the specified form and show the number of ballot papers for the constituency supplied to the Presiding Officer under section 40(2) and account for those ballot papers under the following heads—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the number of ballot papers estimated by the Presiding Officer to be in the ballot box or boxes;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the number of un-issued ballot papers;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the number of unused ballot papers; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the number of spoilt ballot papers.

subsection.leadIn: The Presiding Officer of a dedicated polling station must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: (if one or more ballot papers have been issued by the Presiding Officer on the polling day) prepare a statement which complies with subsection (4) for each constituency in respect of which ballot papers have been issued; or (19 of 2023 s. 146)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: (if no ballot paper has been issued by the Presiding Officer on the polling day) prepare a statement in the specified form confirming that no ballot paper has been issued by the Presiding Officer on the polling day. (L.N. 74 of 2011)

subsection.leadIn: The statement prepared under subsection (3)(a) must be in the specified form and show the number of ballot papers for the constituency supplied to the Presiding Officer under section 40(2) and account for those ballot papers under the following heads— (19 of 2023 s. 146)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the number of ballot papers estimated by the Presiding Officer to be in the ballot box or boxes;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the number of un-issued ballot papers;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the number of unused ballot papers;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the number of spoilt ballot papers. (L.N. 74 of 2011)

part.name: P4
part.heading: Counting of the Votes: Ordinary Election and By-elections

section.name: s65
section.heading: Returning Officer and Presiding Officer to give notice of place and time of the counting of votes to candidates

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (6), the Presiding Officer is to determine the time at which the counting of votes is to begin. (L.N. 125 of 2003)
The time determined under subsection (1) must be a time after the poll has closed at all the polling stations at which polling for the constituency concerned was conducted.

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.leadIn: Despite subsection (2), the time determined under subsection (1) in respect of sorting ballot papers at the ballot paper sorting station—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must be a time after the poll has closed at all the dedicated polling stations situated in prisons at which polling for the constituency concerned was conducted; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may be a time before the poll has closed at all the other polling stations at which polling for the constituency concerned is conducted. (L.N. 131 of 2009)

subsection.content: The Returning Officer must give notice in writing to each candidate of the place or places at which counting is to take place for the constituency contested by the candidate. (L.N. 125 of 2003 and L.N. 191 of 2003)
Notice under subsection (3) must be given at least 10 days before polling day. (L.N. 125 of 2003 and L.N. 191 of 2003; 12 of 2014 s. 102)
If a poll for a constituency is adjourned under Schedule 1, the counting of the votes for that constituency is to stand postponed.

If the counting of the votes stands postponed under subsection (5), the Chief Electoral Officer is to determine a time for the counting to begin and the place or places for it to take place. The time must be after the adjourned poll is resumed and after the close of that poll. The Returning Officer is to give notice to each candidate of the constituency concerned of the time and place.
A notice required to be given under this section may be given to the election agent or counting agent of a candidate instead of the candidate. (L.N. 125 of 2003 and L.N. 191 of 2003)

The Presiding Officer must, before the counting of votes begins, display a notice in a prominent place outside the counting station stating the time that the counting station will be opened to the public to observe the counting of votes. (L.N. 125 of 2003)

def.name: PresidingOfficer
def.leadIn: In this section, Presiding Officer (投票站主任) does not include— (L.N. 131 of 2009)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a Presiding Officer of a small polling station;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a Presiding Officer of a special polling station; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a Presiding Officer of a dedicated polling station. (L.N. 125 of 2003 and L.N. 191 of 2003; L.N. 131 of 2009)

section.name: s66
section.heading: Candidates may appoint counting agents

subsection.content: A candidate may appoint persons to attend at a counting station to observe the counting of the votes for the constituency contested by the candidate, in accordance with this section.
The maximum number of counting agents that a candidate may appoint for one counting station is 2. (L.N. 125 of 2003)
Only a person who is a holder of an identity card and has attained the age of 18 years may be appointed as a counting agent.
A candidate must give notice of appointment of a counting agent to the Returning Officer at least 7 days before polling day. (L.N. 125 of 2003)

subsection.name: 4A
subsection.content: A notice of appointment given under subsection (4) must be delivered by hand, by post, by electronic mail or by facsimile transmission. (12 of 2014 s. 45)

subsection.leadIn: If notice is not given under subsection (4), it must be delivered on polling day to the Presiding Officer— (L.N. 125 of 2003)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by the candidate in person; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by the election agent of the candidate, in person.

subsection.content: A notice of appointment must be in writing and in the specified form. It must state the name, identity card number and residential address of the counting agent. It must be signed by the candidate. (12 of 2014 s. 45)
The appointment of a counting agent is not effective until notice of the appointment is received by the Returning Officer or the Presiding Officer, as may be appropriate. (L.N. 125 of 2003)

If the appointment of a counting agent is revoked, the candidate must give notice of the revocation to the Returning Officer or the Presiding Officer in accordance with subsection (9A) or (10). (L.N. 79 of 2007; 12 of 2014 s. 45)
A notice of revocation must be in writing and in the specified form. It must be signed by the candidate.

subsection.name: 9A
subsection.content: If the notice of revocation is given before polling day, it must be delivered to the Returning Officer by hand, by post, by electronic mail or by facsimile transmission. (12 of 2014 s. 45)

subsection.leadIn: If the notice of revocation is given on polling day, it must be delivered to the Presiding Officer—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by the candidate in person; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by the election agent of the candidate, in person. (12 of 2014 s. 45)

subsection.content: The revocation of the appointment of a counting agent is not effective until notice of revocation is received by the Returning Officer or the Presiding Officer, as may be appropriate. (L.N. 125 of 2003)

section.name: s66A
section.heading: Appointment of Presiding Officer of ballot paper sorting station

subsection.content: The Chief Electoral Officer must appoint a Presiding Officer to preside at each ballot paper sorting station.
The Chief Electoral Officer may, at any time, with reasonable cause, revoke any appointment made under subsection (1).

section.name: s67
section.heading: Chief Electoral Officer to appoint or remove counting officers

subsection.content: The Chief Electoral Officer may appoint persons that Officer considers suitable, as counting officers, to assist a Presiding Officer in counting the votes.
The Chief Electoral Officer must supply to the Presiding Officer a list of the counting officers appointed to assist the Presiding Officer.
The Chief Electoral Officer must display the list of counting officers in a prominent place within the relevant counting station or stations.
The Chief Electoral Officer may, at any time, with reasonable cause revoke the appointment of any counting officer. (L.N. 79 of 2007)

section.name: s68
section.heading: Who may be present at the counting of votes

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsections (2) and (5), only the Returning Officer, Assistant Returning Officers, Presiding Officer, Deputy Presiding Officer and Assistant Presiding Officers and the following persons may be present at the counting of the votes— (L.N. 125 of 2003)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: counting officers;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: candidates;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: election agents and counting agents;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: members of the Commission;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the Chief Electoral Officer;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: police officers on duty at the counting station;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: members of the Civil Aid Service on duty at the counting station;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: public officers authorized in writing by the Chief Electoral Officer; or

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: persons authorized in writing by a member of the Commission.

subsection.content: No other person may be present except with the permission of the Returning Officer or the Presiding Officer.

The Presiding Officer is to ensure that the arrangements for the counting of the votes are such that the candidates and their respective election agents or counting agents are able to observe how individual votes are counted.

Only an election agent or counting agent regarding whom notice of appointment has been given under this Regulation may be present during the counting of the votes at the counting zone or zones. On arriving at the counting station, an election agent or counting agent must report in person to the Presiding Officer and produce his or her identity card and a declaration of secrecy completed on the specified form by him or her.

The Presiding Officer may, if that Officer considers it appropriate and practicable to do so without prejudicing the secrecy of the individual votes and considers that it will not cause disorder or disturbance in the counting station, permit members of the public to observe the counting of the votes from an area at the counting station set apart for that purpose by that Officer. The area is to be at such a distance from the place where the votes are being counted as that Officer considers appropriate.

section.name: s69
section.heading: What constitutes an offence at a counting station

subsection.leadIn: A person who, during the relevant period, films or takes photographs or makes any audio or video recording within a counting zone of a counting station without the express permission of— (L.N. 74 of 2011)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the relevant Returning Officer or Presiding Officer; or (L.N. 125 of 2003)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any member of the Commission,

subsection.continued: commits an offence.

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: In subsection (1)—
subsection.def: relevant period (有關期間), in relation to a counting zone, means the period commencing at the time, determined under section 65, at which the counting of the votes is to begin at the zone and ending upon the completion of the counting and re-count, if any, at the zone. (L.N. 74 of 2011)

subsection.content: A person who fails to comply with a lawful order given by the Presiding Officer at or in the vicinity of a counting station or behaves in a disorderly manner there commits an offence. (L.N. 125 of 2003)
A person who commits an offence under this section is liable to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 3 months.

section.name: s70
section.heading: Presiding Officer to keep order at the counting station

subsection.content: The Presiding Officer must keep order at the counting station.

subsection.leadIn: If, at or in the vicinity of a counting station, a person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: misconducts himself or herself, the Presiding Officer may; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: fails to obey a lawful order of the Presiding Officer, that Officer may,

subsection.continued: order the person to leave the counting station or the vicinity of the counting station, as the case may be, immediately.

subsection.content: If a person fails to leave when ordered to do so under subsection (2), the person may be removed by a police officer or by a person authorized in writing by the Presiding Officer.
A person who is removed under subsection (3) may not enter the relevant counting station again on that day, unless the Officer who ordered his or her removal permits him or her to do so.

section.name: s72
section.heading: Arrangements for the supervision of counting stations and counting zones

subsection.content: The Presiding Officer is to supervise the counting station and the counting zone. (L.N. 125 of 2003)
The Presiding Officer may have one Deputy Presiding Officer and one or more Assistant Presiding Officers to assist him or her. (L.N. 125 of 2003)

def.name: PresidingOfficer
def.leadIn: In this section, Presiding Officer (投票站主任) does not include— (L.N. 131 of 2009)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a Presiding Officer of a small polling station;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a Presiding Officer of a special polling station; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a Presiding Officer of a dedicated polling station. (L.N. 125 of 2003 and L.N. 191 of 2003; L.N. 131 of 2009)

section.name: s74
section.heading: Presiding Officer to open ballot box

subsection.content: A Presiding Officer other than a Presiding Officer of a small polling station which is not designated as a main counting station or a special polling station which is not so designated must open a ballot box in that Officer’s charge by breaking the seal. The Presiding Officer must do so in the presence of the candidates, their election agents or counting agents, if present at the counting zone. (L.N. 125 of 2003 and L.N. 191 of 2003)

The Presiding Officer must permit a candidate, or the election agent or counting agent of a candidate, to inspect any paper, other than a ballot paper, taken from the ballot box, if so requested by the candidate or agent, before that paper is disposed of. A candidate or an election agent or a counting agent must not be permitted under this subsection to inspect a ballot paper. (L.N. 125 of 2003)

section.name: s75
section.heading: Presiding Officer to verify number of ballot papers

subsection.leadIn: A Presiding Officer (other than a Presiding Officer of a main counting station or a ballot paper sorting station) in charge of a counting zone must— (L.N. 125 of 2003 and L.N. 191 of 2003; L.N. 131 of 2009; L.N. 74 of 2011)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: after counting the votes in accordance with section 76, verify the number of ballot papers so counted by comparing it with the ballot paper account prepared under section 64 and prepare a statement in writing as to the result of the verification. (L.N. 125 of 2003)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: A Presiding Officer in charge of a counting zone of a main counting station— (L.N. 131 of 2009; 12 of 2014 s. 72)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: must—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: count and record the number of ballot papers in the ballot box or boxes from a small polling station, a special polling station or a dedicated polling station, and verify the number by comparing it with the ballot paper account prepared under section 64;

subparagraph.name: ii
